abstract: A new recommendation that healthy men need not be screened for prostate cancer is sending a message that many doctors and patients do not want to hear: that early detection does not necessarily save lives.
snippet: A new recommendation that healthy men need not be screened for prostate cancer is sending a message that many doctors and patients do not want to hear: that early detection does not necessarily save lives.
lead_paragraph: The outcry among many physicians and patients over a government panel's recent announcement that healthy men should no longer receive P.S.A. blood testing to detect prostate cancer is rooted in a long and impassioned history among cancer screening advocates that early detection must always save lives. But as science has taught us, that's not always the case.

headline.main: The Shortfalls of Early Cancer Detection
